Date Class

The functionality to create Date objects from strings and create strings from objects is not implemented, but otherwise, it is almost entirely compatible with JavaScript's Date class.

The constructor syntax is as follows:

new Date();
new Date(<date string>);
new Date(<year>, <month(0-)=0>, <day=1>, <hour=0>, <minute=0>, <second=0>);
The first syntax requires no arguments. In this case, it holds the current date and time at the moment the constructor is executed.
The second syntax specifies a date string. The date string must be in one of the following formats: ANSI C asctime() format, those defined in RFC1123, those defined in RFC1036, or "YYYY/MM/DD HH:MM:SS". Recognition of the date string is automatic and accommodates some format variations, but it may not be recognized if it differs significantly from the expected formats.
The third syntax specifies the year, month, day, hour, minute, and second.

Implemented methods (JavaScript compatible):
setYear/getYear (Set/Get the 4-digit year in local time)
setMonth/getMonth (Set/Get the month in local time)
setDate/getDate (Set/Get the day of the month in local time)
setHours/getHours (Set/Get the hour in local time)
setMinutes/getMinutes (Set/Get the minutes in local time)
setSeconds/getSeconds (Set/Get the seconds in local time)
setTime/getTime (Set/Get the elapsed milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 0:00)
getDay (Get the day of the week)
parse (Parse a date string)
